Comment:
Hi everyone!

It is my turn to make a blunder, in fact this game turns into a right comedy of errors on both sides so maybe a draw at the end was a fair result!

Joanne
2. Bf4 - Trompowsky - an aggressive move in a d4 pawn opening and this has netted GM Julian Hodgson quite a few victims.

21. ........ Bxd5?? - this move should have conceded 12 rating points.  I should have played Rxc1 first.  Now white initiates the exchange and emerges a pawn up.  This is the first of the comedy of errors though.

23. ........ Qd7 - I am trying to compose myself after that pawn loss.  Worse I have also conceded the bishop pair and don't those white prelates look powerful.  Luckily my gut instinct says Play On, look for positives - well, I can only try.

32. Bd3? - not the best move.  Now I have the chance to get rid of the Wicked Witch at the cost of Glenda but this means that I remain a pawn up and Henry can breathe more easily!

34. ..... Ne6 - the pawn on d6 cannot be taken because if I do then Henry will certainly be taken, by Old Matey dropping onto e8 - beware of the long range white lsb controlling h7!  This knight move prepares the possibility of the capture on d6.

35. ....... Rxd6 - I decide to remove the d pawn - I did analyse the board and thought that I could not hold onto both my queenside pawns.  As a result I offered my opponent a draw.  Ion, however thought that I could have held onto my a pawn and gradually nursed it up the board, so let's throw in a Bad Draw Offer folks!  I lost 1.9 rating points as a result of the low draw, but maybe after the way I played I was very lucky the loss wasn't 11.9!
